Serving as the Middle School Spirit Squad Coach 25-26 Season at Kennedy Middle School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The Swimming Intramurals Head Coach 25-26 Season position at Kennedy Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. JOB DESCRIPTION --------------------------------- The Chicago Public School (CPS) has set ambitious goals to ensure that every child – in every school and every neighborhood- has access to a world-class learning experience from birth, resulting in graduation from high school college- and career-ready.
High School Athletic coaches instruct and work with athletes to prepare them form competition. Coaches help athletes to play their best individually or as a team in sports such as football, baseball, basketball, lacrosse, track and field, soccer, tennis and golf. They are experts on the rules, strategies, and techniques of their sports. Coaches must also know about sports equipment, physical fitness and safety.
The High School Athletic Coach will be held accountable for the following responsibilities:
Hold tryouts for students of a high school to attend. By observing the students skills with trial and practices, decides who makes the tryout cuts. With an organized team, the high school coach then begins to train the students throughout the preseason process. Assigns everyone specific positions and comes up with drills and organized game strategies. After the season starts, arrives at every game and guides their team throughout the match-ups. If any necessary changes have to be made during the game, they will be in charge of authorizing and implementing them. Continue this process throughout the year with different sports they are assigned to coach.
In order to be successful and achieve the above responsibilities, the High School Athletic Coach must possess the following qualifications:
IHSA QUALIFICATIONS OF A COACH To serve a member school as a Head or Assistant Coach, athletic coaches in member schools must:
Be regularly certified by the ISBE as a teacher, administrator, or school service personnel (i.e. counselor, social worker, speech therapist, etc., including substitute teachers), or Be a retired teacher/coach from an IHSA member school, or Be a college student coaching as part of an official student teaching assignment, or Be at least 19 years of age, and Be officially employed by the local school board of the member school.
In addition to the IHSA qualifications, the High School Athletic Coach must also possess the following qualifications:
MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:
Certifications: Completion of a certified HKCE, NFHS or other IHSA Board approved coaches certification program. Coaches must complete concussion awareness training and a Concussion Management Program Examination in accordance with IHSA requirements.
Skills, and Abilities:
Must possess leadership skills, and be able to set an example for the players. Excellent communication skills in order to inspire players and work with them on improvement. Must be available to work nights, holidays, evenings and weekends, and be prepared to work in bad weather and be willing to travel with the team to different locations for games.

This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (OH) prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Oswego Community D, the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (OH) works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (OH) encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (OH) at Oswego Community D is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Girls Basketball Assistant at Dunlap High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Varsity Girls Basketball Assistant is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Dunlap High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Varsity Girls Basketball Assistant helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Varsity Girls Basketball Assistant works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Dunlap High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Dunlap High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Varsity Girls Basketball Assistant reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Varsity Girls Basketball Assistant role at Dunlap High School.

Job.JobDescription:
Urbana School District #116
TITLE: Athletic Coach
LOCATION: Urbana Middle School
SUPERVISOR: Athletic Director/Associate Principal, Urbana Middle School
JOB SUMMARY: Under general direction of the Athletic Director/Associate Principal, this position is responsible for coaching and providing direction to student athletes so that they have the opportunity to achieve a high level of skill as well as an appreciation for discipline, sportsmanship and teamwork in their respective sport.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential function satisfactorily.
Holds organizational meetings for team prospects and encourages potential athletes to participate in the sport. Assesses players skills and assigns team positions. Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both individual and team development. Works with the athletics director in scheduling facilities for practices and competition. Assigns duties to an assistant coach as necessary (if applicab). Coaches and instructs players, individually or in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment and techniques of the sport. Observes players, during competition and practice to determine the needs for individual or team improvement. Determines game strategy based on the team’s capabilities. Establishes and maintains standards of pupil behavior and provides proper supervision of athletes at all times. Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility requirements are met; and encourages student athletes to maintain a high academic standard. Follows established procedures in the event of an athlete’s injury. Conferences with parents/guardians, as necessary, regarding the athletic performance of their student. Follows state, regional and district regulations governing the athletic program. Models sports-like behavior and maintains appropriate conduct towards players, officials and spectators. Acts as a team representative and promotes the sport by communicating with the news media, booster clubs, service clubs and other organizations. Follows established procedures for the proper care, maintenance and requisitioning of equipment, supplies and uniforms. Works with the athletic director to develop a policy for awards and submits a list of award winners at the end of the season. Participates in special activities to include parent’s night, banquets, award nights and pep assemblies. Maintains eligibility forms, emergency data cards, insurance records, equipment inventory and other related records. Models nondiscriminatory practices in all activities.
ADDITIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES:
Attends staff development meetings, clinics and other professional activities to improve coaching performance. Performs any other related duties as assigned by the Principal & Athletic Director or other appropriate administrator.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Illinois Teaching License ASEP Certification Illinois Substitute Teaching Certificate
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT:
Salary and Benefit information can be found on the Human Resources webpage. This is not a position within the collective bargaining unit and is not an administrative position.
EVALUATION: Performance of this job will be evaluated by the current supervisor, Athletic Director/Assistant Principal and/or head coach of the program.
START DATE: Spring 2026
AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER
REVISED: April, 2025
Position Type: 0.25 FTE
Contact Information Derek Ely , Associate Principal Urbana Middle School Phone: 217 384 3685

Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach, Mens Soccer Coach (part-time) at Illinois Valley Community College is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head Coach, Mens Soccer Coach (part-time) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Illinois Valley Community College, the Head Coach, Mens Soccer Coach (part-time) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Head Coach, Mens Soccer Coach (part-time) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Illinois Valley Community College well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Head Coach, Mens Soccer Coach (part-time) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: High School Boys Assistant Football Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The High School Boys Assistant Football Coach at Perry Meridian High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the High School Boys Assistant Football Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Perry Meridian High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The High School Boys Assistant Football Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the High School Boys Assistant Football Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the High School Boys Assistant Football Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Perry Meridian High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

If no coaches are available from the faculty members or certificated teachers employed if the following procedures are followed: (a) With no acceptable professional staff members available to fill the coaching vacancy, the local school system shall attempt to locate as a coach a person certifiable as a professional educator by the Maryland State Department of Education (b) With no acceptable and certifiable professional educator available a person acceptable to the local school system may be employed as an emergency coach. (c) Any person employed as a coach under the emergency provision shall comply with the following: (I) The person shall be officially appointed by the local school system on a one-season basis for a specific coaching assignment. (II) The coaching salary of the appointed emergency coach shall be paid exclusively by the local school system. (III) The emergency coach shall attend the MPSSAA annual rules clinic for that sport in which the coaching will take place. (IV) The emergency coach shall complete the equivalent of a one-credit course in the prevention and care of athletic injuries. (V) In sports having more than one coach, emergency coaches cannot comprise more than 50 percent of that staff. In only those sports designated by the local school system as a one coach sport, and emergency coach may be employed as head or varsity coach. Job.JobDescription:
The Wrestling Assistant Coach position at Hillcrest High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Wrestling Assistant Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Hillcrest High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Wrestling Assistant Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Wrestling Assistant Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Wrestling Assistant Coach role at Hillcrest High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Basketball coach role at Century High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Assistant Girls Basketball coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Century High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Assistant Girls Basketball coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Century High School, the Assistant Girls Basketball coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Assistant Girls Basketball coach at Century High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Track Assistant Coach position at Vallivue High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Varsity Track Assistant Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Varsity Track Assistant Coach at Vallivue High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Vallivue High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Varsity Track Assistant Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Varsity Track Assistant Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Varsity Track Assistant Coach position at Vallivue High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

II. QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Demonstrates skill and experience in the sport coached. 2. Holds a valid Idaho Teaching Certificate or certified by the ASEP or NFICEP. 3. Attends appropriate meetings and serves on committees as requested by the Building Administrator and Head Coach. 8. Maintains a direct line of communication with administration. 9. Maintains high standards and promotes ethical conduct and confidentiality. 10. Performs all other duties as assigned.

Job.JobDescription:
PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY TO Building Principal and Athletics and Activities Director
JOB SUMMARY To motivate and develop each athletes' skills, attitudes, and habits that will guide them toward success, personal growth, and good character. To provide examples of fair play, team building, and respect. Provide leadership and motivation to excel.
MAJOR DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Working with Student Athletes 1. Attend all tryouts, practice meetings, and in-school events, and supervise students during related field trips and other out-of-school functions 2. Organize practice schedules and game rosters 3. Assign positions to players, and develop strategies and styles of play 4. Organize, maintain, & inventory facilities, equipment, & uniforms 5. Attend out-of-school meetings, supervise fundraisers, and help students prepare for competitions 6. Arrange and participate in off-season workouts 7. Coach individual participants of varying abilities in the skills necessary 8. Track student performance throughout the season 9. Arrange with the athletics and activities director for any necessary transportation, scheduling, hiring of officials, or other arrangements for competitions related to the sport 10. Ensure the safety of the students and maintain responsibility for the security of equipment and facilities and ensure that safety equipment is used correctly 11. Comply with federal and state law, administrative rules, and Board policy pertaining to medical procedures and student athletes, including the district's concussion policy 12. Ensure that students are eligible to participate, and that they have had any necessary physical examinations 13. Actively promote the athletic program, seek student participation, and select team members 14. Model positive behavior, maintain a supportive environment, and remain professional, even when tension is high 15. Maintain high standards of conduct for student athletes, including respect and fair play 16. Abide by the rules of the Idaho High School Activities Association Handbook EVALUATION Performance of this position will be evaluated periodically by the building principal and/or the athletics and activities director in conformance with district policy and IDAPA 08.02.02.120. TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT By contract as determined by the Board of Trustees in accordance with federal and state law, administrative rules, and Board policy. NOTE All certificated and non-certificated employees and other individuals are required to undergo a criminal history check and submit to fingerprinting. Any applicant convicted of any of the felony crimes enumerated in Section 33-1208, Idaho Code may not be hired, and any applicant convicted of any felony offense listed in Section 33-1208(2), Idaho Code shall not be hired. Job.JobDescription:
The General Coaching position at Belvidere Community D is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The General Coaching is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Belvidere Community D, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The General Coaching encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The General Coaching also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the General Coaching role at Belvidere Community D is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Indoor/Outdoor Boys Track Coach at Harlem High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Assistant Indoor/Outdoor Boys Track Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Harlem High School, the Assistant Indoor/Outdoor Boys Track Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Assistant Indoor/Outdoor Boys Track Coach may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Harlem High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Assistant Indoor/Outdoor Boys Track Coach follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach Baseball position at Lake Zurich High School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Coach Baseball works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Coach Baseball at Lake Zurich High School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Lake Zurich High School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Coach Baseball encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Coach Baseball is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Coach Baseball position at Lake Zurich High School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription: The Assistant Athletic Trainer will support and assist the Head Athletic Trainer to provides prevention, care, and rehabilitation services for student-athlete athletic injuries in compliance with all institutional, National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and other national and conference policies and guidelines. The role provides athletic training coverage for team practices and competitions based on season and sport assignment as designated by Head Athletic Trainer. The Assistant Athletic Trainer collaborates with physicians and physical therapists for off-campus appointments, evaluation, diagnostic testing, rehabilitation, and medical clearance of athletic injuries. Additionally, this position will aid in the management of the athletic training room, maintain comprehensive records of athletic injuries and treatments, formulate effective therapeutic treatment and rehabilitation plans and make referrals, and communicate regularly with coaching and administrative staff. The role will assist with the development of the department’s Emergency Action Plan, as well as insurance related inquiries and the submission of any needed documentation, while performing other job-related duties as assigned. This is a a full-time, exempt position that reports to the Head Athletic Trainer. The primary work location is the Chicago campus, with work also conducted at off-site home athletic facilities. Knowledge, Skills and Abilities Required • Bachelor’s Degree • National Athletic Trainers’ Association Board of Certification • Illinois Athletic Training Licensure • First Aid / CPR / AED Certified • Valid driver’s license with the ability to travel with University teams as required • Ability to work nights, weekends and select holidays during athletic seasons • Excellent organizational, communication (written and verbal), interpersonal skills and attention to detail • Ability to exercise considerable judgment and discretion in establishing and maintaining good working relationships • Ability to demonstrate a commitment to service excellence by embodying Roosevelt’s core values, mission, and vision in every aspect of the role working with students, faculty, staff, and visitors • A positive and professional demeanor is a must • Demonstrated proficiency in Microsoft Office Suite including Word, Excel, and Outlook Years of Experience Required: 0-3 Required Education: Bachelor's Degree Certification/Licensure Required: • National Athletic Trainers’ Association Board of Certification • Illinois Athletic Training Licensure • First Aid / CPR / AED Certified Minimum Qualifications: Please refer to knowledge, skills, and abilities required. Preferred Qualifications: • Master’s degree in a related field • Mental Health First Aid (MHFA), • Instrument Assisted Soft Tissue Mobilization (IASTM), • National Academy of Sports Medicine (NASM) or other professional certification • Prior experience as a collegiate athletic trainer
